title: 107_s1686
content: The Act may be cited as the "Safe Nursing and Patient Care Act of 2001". The Congress finds that higher nurse staffing levels lead to better patient outcomes, but there are challenges in recruiting and retaining nursing staff. About 500,000 licensed nurses are not practicing nursing due to job dissatisfaction and overtime work. The widespread use of mandatory overtime in nursing contributes to job dissatisfaction and fatigue among nurses, leading to medical errors and compromising patient safety. Limiting mandatory overtime can help address these issues. Limiting mandatory overtime in healthcare facilities nationwide ensures public safety, quality care delivery, and aids in nurse retention and recruitment. SEC. 3. LIMITATIONS ON MANDATORY OVERTIME FOR NURSES. Section 1866 of the Social Security Act is amended to include limitations on mandatory overtime for nurses. Limitations on mandatory overtime for nurses include prohibiting nurses from working beyond their scheduled shift, 12 hours in a 24-hour period, or 80 hours in a consecutive 14-day period, with exceptions allowed. During a declared state of emergency, providers of services may be exempt from certain requirements if they are expected to deliver an exceptional level of medical services to the community. Nurses can only be mandated to work beyond specified periods under certain conditions. During a state of emergency, providers must make efforts to fill staffing needs and work requirements should not extend past the end of the emergency. During a state of emergency, nurses have the right to report violations by healthcare providers to the Secretary. The Secretary will establish a procedure for nurses to file complaints, which will be investigated. During a state of emergency, nurses can report violations by healthcare providers to the Secretary, who will investigate complaints and take action against violators, including requiring a plan of action and imposing civil money penalties. Nurses are protected from discrimination by providers of services. During a state of emergency, nurses are protected from discrimination by healthcare providers. Providers of services cannot penalize, discriminate, or retaliate against nurses who refuse mandatory overtime or report violations to regulatory agencies. During a state of emergency, nurses are protected from discrimination by healthcare providers, including penalties for refusing overtime or reporting violations to regulatory agencies. During a state of emergency, nurses are protected from discrimination by healthcare providers, including penalties for refusing overtime or reporting violations to regulatory agencies. Nurses cannot be retaliated against for refusing to work mandatory overtime. During a state of emergency, nurses are protected from discrimination by healthcare providers. Nurses are deemed to be acting in good faith if they believe the reported information is true and a violation has occurred or may occur. Providers of services must post a notice specifying nurses' rights under this section. Providers of services must post nurse schedules in a visible manner and include information on filing complaints against violators. The Secretary may impose a civil money penalty of up to $10,000 for each knowing violation of nurse schedule posting requirements by a provider of services. The Secretary may impose more severe civil money penalties on providers of services for repeated violations. The penalties will be administered in the same manner as other provisions under section 1128A. The names of providers will be published on the Department of Health and Human Services website. The Department of Health and Human Services publishes the names of providers who have been penalized with civil money penalties, along with details of the violations. Penalties imposed on providers under previous ownership will not be published after a 1-year period from the change in ownership. The subsection prohibits mandatory overtime for nurses exceeding specified periods, allowing voluntary work beyond limits if safe patient care standards are maintained. The subsection prohibits mandatory overtime for nurses, defining overtime as work exceeding specified periods. A nurse is defined as a registered provider of services who may face adverse employment consequences if refusing a request that could result in discharge, discipline, loss of promotion, or retaliatory reporting. The term 'nurse' refers to a registered nurse or a licensed practical nurse. The term 'provider of services' includes various healthcare facilities such as hospitals, outpatient departments, critical access hospitals, ambulatory surgical centers, home health agencies, rehabilitation agencies, and clinics. The term 'declared state of emergency' refers to an officially designated state of emergency declared by the Federal Government or the head of the appropriate State or local governmental agency. The term 'standards of safe patient care' refers to professional standards for nurses. Amendments will take effect one year after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 4. REPORTS. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will conduct a study to establish safe working hour standards for nurses providing healthcare, considering various factors like provider type, department, duties, and shifts. The Director may contract with an eligible entity to carry out a study on appropriate standards of maximum work hours. The Secretary will submit a report to Congress with recommendations within 2 years. Additionally, the Director of the Office of Management and Budget will conduct a study on mandatory overtime in federally operated medical facilities. Management and Budget will study federally operated medical facilities to determine if their practices regarding nurses' overtime requirements comply with section 1866(j) of the Social Security Act. Federally operated medical facilities include acute care hospitals, freestanding clinics, and home health care. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will report to Congress on the study of federally operated medical facilities' compliance with nurses' overtime requirements. Recommendations for policy implementation will be included. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will report to Congress on the study of federally operated medical facilities' compliance with nurses' overtime requirements, including recommendations for policy implementation.
